doc.title: G10: Strongest Directional Signals
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Global FX FX Flows Weekly EM Aggregate flipped to inflow zone EM Aggregate flipped to inflow zoneGlobal FX FX Flows Week_2025-08-29

passages.text: EM Aggregate flipped to inflow zone
With thanks to: Mike Alexeev, rEm Sen, Stanley Ren

Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Certain products (not inconsistent with the author's published research) are available only on

Citi Flows - EM aggregate flows flipped to inflow zone with both real money and leveraged investors turning to net buyers. By region, LatAm continued to witness outflows mainly led by banks, albeit at slower pace. Asia received inflows on the back of inflows seen from both real money and leveraged investors. Flows in CEEMEA were rather muted last week, with light outflows mainly led by leveraged investors and corporates.

Quant - Flows currently favor CNY, IDR & SGD against TRY, MXN & CLP. Traditional carry positioning is crowded on a 1m and 6m basis for leveraged investors. Momentum is also crowded on a 1m basis; Value positioning is clean. Vol- adjusted carry (EMFX 5x5) positioning is crowded on a 6m basis, but clean in the 1m and 3m tenors.

Cross- asset vol is below the 70th percentile. In terms of crowded basket at risk from a vol spike, TRY, CZK & TWD are the most vulnerable, having been net bought by our investor base. THB, KRW & MYR saw the most outflows over the last three months.
G10 - Our flows indicate modest USD & safe haven selling vs buying of higher beta G10 FX. Leveraged flows experienced sharp divergence for the Scandies (SEK selling, NOK buying).

Asia - Investor flows in Asia reversed to positive territory with both real money and leveraged investors turning to net buyers. There were notable selling in THB from real money investors. In contrast, there were meaningful buying in IDR from real money investors and in CNH from leveraged investors.
CEEMEA - CEEMEA saw muted flows this week overall, in line with the EM aggregate. Within CEEMEA, CZK and ILS saw inflows, while the rest muted flows overall.

LatAm - Flows in the region were in line with overall EM aggregates this week, with marginal net inflows being observed by leveraged and real money accounts, while banks were net sellers. Notably, BRL saw inflows across the whole investor base. CLP saw outflows from leveraged investors, which instead bought all the other regional currencies, in particular MXN.

Our latest flows data indicate buying of more cyclical currencies like AUD, NZD, NOK, and CAD. Each was driven by a mix of leveraged and real money buying against selling of safe haven currencies like JPY, CHF, and EUR. Broader commodities indices have been trending higher of late, in line with soft data improving across major economies, tariff uncertainty largely in the rearview mirror, and geopolitical developments. This has also occurred against a backdrop of modest USD selling and follow- through of dovish Fed expectations around Chair Powell's Jackson Hole remarks. The bigger question then becomes will risk assets trade 'bad news as good news' if the next US NFP report is weak, per Citi Economics expectations.
Select G10 Indexed Weekly Flows: Leveraged Segment
Asia: Expect RMB outperformance in coming months
Weekly avg indexed flows in CNH, latest 5 weeks

Citi flows data suggests an accelerating inflow pace seen in CNH over the past four weeks. We believe there is room for RMB to appreciate in the next few months for the following reasons:1) Sentiment around Chinese equities seems to be running high driven by liquidity; 2) PBOC's fixing bias has clearly been towards RMB appreciation since May; 3) FX hoarding from Chinese exporters has reduced considerably since Q2. 4) political need for RMB appreciation to show some goodwill as we head into possible US- China summit in the next few months. We express this view by going long 2m USD put/CNH call ATMF.

CZK has been one of the best performing currencies in the EM space since Liberation day. CZK REER is also trading near its all- time highs, helped by the move in EURUSD this year and the hawkish turn from the central bank. Within our flow metrics as well, CZK has cumulatively seen the strongest inflows in the last one year when compared to the rest of CEEMEA currencies, from both real money and leveraged accounts. This has been helped by CNB keeping a hawkish tone, as markets have priced not only the end of the easing cycle but also hiking risk premia. The latest GDP print out this week also surprised on the upside versus consensus, indicating strong growth momentum. This is likely to keep on feeding through the Koruna. We believe the current set up of weaker broad dollar heading into the Fed cut, combined with political pressure on Fed and CNB's hawkishness could keep the currency on an appreciation trend.
Cumulative 1-year indexed flows, CZK
LATAM: Real Money and Leveraged investors continue to portray a bullish picture for Brazil.

Last week BRL began under pressure on the back of tensions between the Supreme Court and the US administration. However, this caused no structural panic among investors, with real money and leveraged accounts at the margin holding on to BRL longs. Last week though ended on a positive note, with Fed Chair Powell delivering a dovish pivot during his speech at Jackson Hole, which helped turn around sentiment in BRL and DI, with the currency and rates reverting to pre- sell off levels by the end of this week. On local developments this week that helped the BRL, news of President Lula's approval rating showing signs of decline was well received by the market as BRL outperformed. However, the move was counterbalanced late this week by the initiation of a process which could lead to retaliation against US tariffs, at the margin bearish, as suggested by DI's marginal pullback. We remain constructive on the macroeconomic picture in Brazil, with our Econ team recently lowering to \(4.8\%\) YoY its 2025 year- end inflation forecast. August bi- weekly inflation print was slightly above consensus, but the print was mainly driven by some adjustments related to tax hikes in the gambling sectors rather than any demand side pressure. For this reason, investors did not seem to be worried, as they used the initial drawback in both FX and rates as an entry point, indicating they remain bullish Brazil. We remain OW BRL in our EM Bond Portfolio.
Cumulative 1-year indexed flows, BRL
The statistics in the previous slide's charts suggest following bank flows (on a 10d and monthly basis) and leveraged fund flows (on a 5d basis) work the best across currencies over the long term.
These flows currently favor CNY, IDR & SGD against TRY, MXN & CLP. 10d Bank flows favor CNY, PHP & IDR against TRY, MXN & ZAR.
This week, leveraged flows were mixed. Inflows favor CNY, TWD & CZK while outflows were concentrated in PHP, THB & PLN.
Crowded basket: Analysis of the medium- term flows from leveraged and real- money investors shows TRY, CZK & TWD as the most vulnerable to a vol shock, having been net bought by our investor base.
THB, KRW & MYR saw the most outflows over the last three months and would therefore be expected to outperform if risk aversion rises above the trigger level.
The volatility signal is below the 70th percentile trigger mark, suggesting such strategies may not be profitable.
Recent flows favor CNY, IDR & SGD against TRY, MXN & CLP
TRY, CZK & TWD most vulnerable to vol shock; THB, KRW & MYR can appreciate

Our volatility measure, an average of equity and FX vol, is below the 70th percentile. When there is a VAR shock (i.e. a move above the 70th percentile), our systematic strategy would fade the currencies that have seen the greatest 3m flows from real money and leveraged clients.
This strategy currently has an active IR of around 1 and triggers, historically, around \(\sim 20\%\) of the time.
Current recommendations are on the previous slide: short TRY, CZK & TWD and long THB, KRW & MYR.
Implied volatility is not triggering our positioning basket.

For popular factors like Carry, Momentum, and Value, leveraged flows above the 80th percentile can reduce subsequent factor returns. These simplest factor expressions are more susceptible to crowding in our view. They are based on ranking each currency and creating a long/short portfolio with a gross leverage of 1.

We prefer vol- adjusting our carry signal and vol- weighting each currency in our own factor work. Currently, in the standard carry strategy, flows indicate crowding on a 1m and 6m basis for leveraged investors. Momentum is also crowded on a 1m basis while Value (PPP) positioning is clean.
Carry monthly forward returns by flow percentile - above 80th percentile, leveraged flows have weaker returns.
Value (PPP) positioning is clean
Momentum positioning also diminishes past 80th percentile
On the right, we show cumulative flows into carry strategies.
Each bar represents the contribution to carry flow by currency i.e., signal \* daily flow accumulated.

We shade the high- yielders as solid bars while low- yielders are given striped bars to differentiate them. The positive bars indicate net flows out of low- yielders such as THB signifying inflows into carry (as they are typically on the short side of the trade), or inflows into high- yielders such as TRY. Negative bars are either higher carry currency selling or buying of the funder.
We also show flows into high or low yielding currencies (in both cases rises / positive are for buying and lower represents selling).

Carry flows from Leveraged investors (top panel) saw near- flat net flows this past week following the previous week's strong inflows. Low yielders saw buying in CNY, TWD & CZK while selling THB and KRW. High yielders saw buying in MXN, BRL & TRY while selling ZAR and PHP.

Carry flows from Real Money investors (bottom panel) saw outflows this past week. Low yielders saw buying in KRW, CNY & CZK while selling THB and TWD. High yielders saw net selling in COP, ZAR & TRY while buying BRL, IDR & INR.
Carry flows from Leveraged investors was a near-flat trend in the past week
Carry flows from Real Money investors saw strong outflows
Since inception of our flow data, carry has consistently been a popular trade amongst leveraged investors, while asset managers have had a time- varying exposure.
Asset managers have preferred medium- term momentum, which we measure here as a blend of 1m, 3m and 6m signals while leveraged funds have consistently allocated away from such strategies.
Both leveraged and real money have allocated to cheap currencies (on a PPP basis), although real money interest has waned recently with leveraged flows catching up.
Carry is more popular among leveraged investors, with rising cumulative flows.
Medium-term momentum is more popular with asset managers, though cumulative inflows are flat.
Value (PPP) cumulative flows from real money are showing recent outflows.
The top five vs bottom five vol- adjusted carry EMFX strategy has been on an upwind recently after a few months of carry unwind.
Implied yields this week indicate longs in TRY, BRL, MXN, INR & COP versus shorts in CNY, SGD, TWD, THB & MYR.
Current crowding readings for this strategy (Top 5 vs Bottom 5 as opposed to our quant team's EMFX factor model which takes a position in the full universe) indicates crowding on a 6m basis.
Crowding lowers returns in top 5 vs bottom 5 vol- adjusted carry. Positioning is clean in 1m and 3m.
Vol Adjusted Carry Performance (Top 5 vs Bottom 5)
Current vol-adjusted carry scores by currency.
When there is a higher differential in carry across our EM universe, the strategy's returns also tend to be higher.
Currently, this differential is around average.
Carry differential has recently gone sideways near its average
Carry dispersion (90th percentile of carry less the 10th) has a positive relationship with forward returns.

CitiFX Flows are available at: https://www.citivelocity.com/cv2/go/FX_FX_FLOW_G10.

The CitiFX Flow Indicator measures the direction and magnitude of net currency flow that clients trade with Citi. The indicator is calculated as daily net flow per currency and client type, normalised by the medium 6- month volume for the currency. A positive values means clients have bought the currency on that day and a negative value means clients have sold the currency.

Flow indicators are calculated by currency rather than currency pair. Net buys and sells of a currency by client type are summed in USD equivalent terms regardless of the cross they are transacted in.
Flows are calculated separately for Corporates, Leveraged Accounts, Real Money and Banks (commercial or investment banks but not market- making flows among dealers)

The FX Flow Indicator aggregates CitiFX client order flows globally on a daily basis by currency across all currency pairs and client types. Steps to calculate daily Net Flow for currency \(j\) and client segment \(k\) are as follows:

1. For each currency, cap the daily net flow of each client so that the absolute net flow is no more than \(25\%\) of the total volume in the relevant currency for the client segment for that day. Retail segment has daily net flow cap of no more than \(15\%\) .

2. Further cap the daily net flow for each client at \(10\%\) (instead of \(25\%\) ) if the 5-day absolute aggregate net flow for a client is greater than \(10\%\) of the 5-day aggregate volume in the same currency for the client segment. Retail segment has a similar cap but at \(3\%\) (instead of \(15\%\) ).
3. Define the Flow Index for each currency as the aggregate capped net flow across clients divided by the median of the past 135-days of daily volume across all client segments.
\[\mathsf{FlowIndex}_{j,k,t} = \frac{\sum_{i}\mathsf{NetFlowCap2}_{i,j,k,t}}{\mathsf{median}(\mathsf{TotalVolume}_{j,t - 124},\mathsf{TotalVolume}_{j,t - 123},\dots,\mathsf{TotalVolume}_{j,t})}\]
4. Cap the index so that its absolute value is no higher than 3x the median of the past 135-day initial flow index values, and multiply value by 100.
\[\mathsf{MedAbsFlowIndex}_{j,k,t} = \mathsf{median}(\mathsf{FlowIndex}_{j,k,t - 124},|\mathsf{FlowIndex}_{j,k,t - 123}|,\dots,|\mathsf{FlowIndex}_{j,k,t}|)\]

\[\mathsf{FinalFlowIndex}_{j,k,t} = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}300 + \mathsf{sign}(\mathsf{FlowIndex}_{j,k,t}) + \mathsf{MedAbsFlowIndex}_{j,k,t}, & \mathsf{if}|\mathsf{FlowIndex}_{j,k,t}| > 3 + \mathsf{MedAbsFlowIndex}_{j,k,t}\\ 100 + \mathsf{FlowIndex}_{j,k,t}, & \mathsf{otherwise} \end{array} \right.\]
5. Set FinalFlowIndexi,k,t to blank (i.e. NULL) if there are less than 3 clients with net flow for currency i, client segment k, and day t.
For more information, please visit Citi Velocity QIS page.
Charts are referenced from top left to bottom right.
Chart 1 - Individual client segments' contribution to total flows over the last five weeks. A positive number is net buying, a negative number is net selling.
Chart 2 - Cumulative flows over the past year by each client segment.
Chart 3 - Breakdown of average weekly indexed flows by client types
Chart 4 - Correlation FX flow with currency returns
Charts 5 & 6 - 4- week flows of leverage and real money client segments, the 10th and 90th percentile of these rolling 4- week flows, and spot prices.

Analysts' compensation is determined by Citi Research management and Citigroup's senior management and is based upon activities and services intended to benefit the investor clients of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. and its affiliates (the "Firm"). Compensation is not linked to specific transactions or recommendations. Like all Firm employees, analysts receive compensation that is impacted by overall Firm profitability which includes investment banking, sales and trading, and principal trading revenues. One factor in equity research analyst compensation is arranging corporate access events between institutional clients and the management teams of covered companies. Typically, company management is more likely to participate when the analyst has a positive view of the company.

For financial instruments recommended in the Product in which the Firm is not a market maker, the Firm is a liquidity provider in such financial instruments (and any underlying instruments) and may act as principal in connection with transactions in such instruments. The Firm is a regular issuer of traded financial instruments linked to securities that may have been recommended in the Product. The Firm regularly trades in the securities of the issuer(s) discussed in the Product. The Firm may engage in securities transactions in a manner inconsistent with the Product and, with respect to securities covered by the Product, will buy or sell from customers on a principal basis.

Unless stated otherwise neither the Research Analyst nor any member of their team has viewed the material operations of the Companies for which an investment view has been provided within the past 12 months.

Citi Research broadly and simultaneously disseminates its research content to the Firm's institutional and retail clients via the Firm's proprietary electronic distribution platforms (e.g., Citi Velocity and various Global Wealth platforms). As a convenience, certain, but not all, research content may be distributed through third party aggregators. Clients may receive published research reports by email, on a discretionary basis, and only after such research content has been broadly disseminated. Certain research is made available only to institutional investors to satisfy regulatory requirements. The level and types of services provided by Citi Research analysts to clients may vary depending on various factors such as the client's individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communications from analysts, the client's risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g. market- wide, sector specific, long term, short- term etc.), the size and scope of the overall client relationship with the Firm and legal and regulatory constraints.

However, it should be presumed that the author of the Product has had discussions with the subject company to ensure factual accuracy prior to publication. Statements and views concerning ESG (environmental, social, governance) factors are typically based upon public statements made by the affected company or other public news, which the author may not have independently verified. ESG factors are one consideration that investors may choose to examine when making investment decisions. All opinions, projections and estimates constitute the judgment of the author as of the date of the Product and these, plus any other information contained in the Product, are subject to change without notice. Prices and availability of financial instruments also are subject to change without notice. Notwithstanding other departments within the Firm advising the companies discussed in this Product, information obtained in such role is not used in the preparation of the Product. Although Citi Research does not set a predetermined frequency for publication, if the Product is a fundamental equity or credit research report, it is the intention of Citi Research to provide research coverage of the covered issuers, including in response to news affecting the issuer. For non- fundamental research reports, Citi Research may not provide regular updates to the views, recommendations and facts included in the reports. Notwithstanding that Citi Research maintains coverage on, makes recommendations concerning or discusses issuers, Citi Research may be periodically restricted from referencing certain issuers due to legal or policy reasons. Where a component of a published trade idea is subject to a restriction, the trade idea will be removed from any list of open trade ideas included in the Product. Upon the lifting of the restriction, the trade idea will either be re- instead in the open trade ideas list if the analyst continues to support it or it will be officially closed. Citi Research may provide different research products and services to different classes of customers (for example, based upon long- term or short- term investment horizons) that may lead to differing conclusions or recommendations that could impact the price of a security contrary to the recommendations in the alternative research product, provided that each is consistent with the rating system for each respective product.
